.- The Committee must be under a great obligation to the honorable member for Mernda for his able, comprehensive, and moderate survey of the financial position. His speech certainly bore evidence of great care, thought, and preparation. In matters of finance, which involve a considerable amount of special knowledge, I think that the honorable member is entitled to a little consideration, and I regret that he was not allowed to complete his speech. The refusal to allow him to continue beyond the time allotted by the Standing Orders has taken us by surprise, and I feel somewhat at a disadvantage in continuing the debate after his unfinished but masterly speech. I cannot hope to make an analysis of the financial features of the Budget in the same critical and searching manner; but that, perhaps, is hardly necessary, in view of the ground already covered. I think it might be convenient to premise a few remarks of a practical character on the Budget by some general observations regarding the conditions under which the financial statement has been presented. This is the third, and, for this Parliament, the last of a series of three financial statements submitted by the present Treasurer during a period of unparalleled prosperity in the history of the Commonwealth. I cannot but congratulate him and his colleagues on the. good fortune they have enjoyed in being in office and in power with a big majority behind them during such a glorious period of prosperity'. Although this has been, apparently, a brilliant financial period, judging from some stand-points of history, there are other features hardly consistent with a period of prosperity, and the promises and policy of the Prime Minister and his colleagues. I should like, in a few sentences, to contrast some of the phases of this period of Labour rule. On the one hand there have been increased imports of merchandise, a larger revenue, higher salaries, more work in the Public Service, larger expenditure, an expansion of Government functions and of opportunities for political patronage; on the other there have been unsatisfactory features requiring consideration and explanation. There has been a remarkable reduction in our exports and in the production of gold, the cost of living has increased, money has become dearer, the power of the banks to give accommodation has been diminished, and the industrial unrest has been remarkable. We were promised that under Labour rule wages would rise and employment increase, but there have been more strikes since this Government took office than in any other similar period of our history. During the last three years no fewer than 220 strikes were recorded in the various States. I gave particulars concerning them on a former occasion, and shall not repeat what I said then. This industrial unrest is in striking contrast to the prosperity which the country has enjoyed. A most extraordinary position was revealed by the deputation which a few weeks ago the Leader of the Opposition in the Parliament of Victoria introduced to the Premier of the State. It complained that there are some 2,000 Victorian artisans now out of work, most of them agricultural implement makers, iron and metal workers, clothing and textile workers, and machinists. An account of the deputation appeared in the Age of the11th July, not long before the delivery of this extraordinary Budget, which discovered a larger revenue and expenditure than we had ever before known in Australia. Evidently the picture, presented with such self-glorification by the Prime Minister, has its reverse side. There is something needing explanation. We were not told why, in the midst of so much activity and prosperity, there should be such dissatisfaction in the ranks of the working classes. We must be thankful for the prosperity we have enjoyed, and glad that the country has so greatly progressed, and must hope that the evils to which I have referred will in time disappear. Apparently we are now on the crest of the wave of prosperity, and two lines in the Budget show that the Treasurer expects the revenue from Customs and Excise to decline, a sign - not greater than a man's hand in the sky, perhaps - that unfavorable developments are approaching. I am afraid that there may be some justification for the apprehension of the honorable member for Mernda that less prosperous times may shortly be upon us. One of the characteristics of the period ot Labour rule has been the increased cost of living, and the higher price of money. Notwithstanding the inflation of revenue and expenditure, money is not so abundant as it was ; it is not so cheap to those who require financial accommodation. Plainly, the Labour party has not fulfilled 'its promise to give us cheaper money and to reduce the cost of living. We were told that, when the Commonwealth Bank had been established and the Australian notes issued, money would be plentiful and cheap ; but one of the immediate results of the note issue has been to raise the rate of discount and to increase the price of money. Careful consideration of the facts shows that the note issue has not realized the hopes held forth on its account. About 4,000,000 sovereigns are locked up in the vaults of the Treasury as a reserve against the note issue. That gold is idle. It has been withdrawn from circulation, and- no longer earns interest; and its withdrawal has reduced the credit of the Commonwealth. A gold reserve is essential to the note system; but the result of the withdrawal of gold from circulation is a reduction of credit. Under the old system, the banks could have lent out the money to the borrowing public; now the necessity is imposed on them of keeping a certain number of Commonwealth notes in their coffers, to be used as till-money. For these notes the banks have paid sovereigns, and have thus diminished their lending power. The statement in the speech delivered some time ago by the honorable member for Mernda, and the evidence of all financial experts, is that the effect of the note issue has been to diminish the financial power of the tanks, to force them to compel their customers to reduce their overdrafts. To that extent it has interfered with the industrial expansion of the Commonwealth, and the business operations of many people in it. I do not say it is the sole factor, but it is undoubtedly one of the factors which account for the financial depression of the. times, and which have to be remembered when credit is claimed for the note issue. The Prime Minister claimed that he had realized about £184,000 net interest on the balance which had been lent to the States and other institutions from the note issue fund. After allowing a certain amount for the expenses of the issue, he said the net profit would be only about £143,000.
- About £184,000 net. There is a difference between the received and accrued amounts.

- It has been already pointed out that, so far as the profits of the note issue are concerned, the Commonwealth Parliament and Government could have had just as much profit by authorizing the banks by legislation to continue issuing notes under Federal sanction and licence, subject to the imposition of a Federal bank note tax. Originally under the State there was a bank note tax of 2 per cent., which realized nearly £100,000 a year. The Federal Government could have imposed a 3 per cent, tax if it had thought fit, and that, coupled with the saving in the cost of issue amounting to £30,000 or £40,000, would have been * just as profitable a proposition as the issue of_notes by the Commonwealth. We should have been financially just as well off, and there would have been the advantage of not inflicting a blow upon the financial institutions of the country, and thereby helping to contribute towards the present financial depression. With the increase of the Australian note issue and the suggested creation of a 10s. bank note, the Treasurer will call into being a very formidable competitor with the Federal money order and postal note business. The charges in connexion with the issue of money orders and postal notes in Australia have been a large and growing source of revenue. In 1906-7 the Postal Department received £92,240 from fees on money orders and postal notes; in 1907-8, £94,624; in 1^08-9, £100,033 > in i9°9-IO> £io4.457 ; and in 1910-.11, £112,568. We have therefore a fine and growing source of revenue in that financial branch of the Postal Department, but it will now find what will probably be a destructive competitor in the Australian note issue. It will therefore be found on ultimate analysis, in my opinion, that the claim put forward on behalf of the Australian note issue, glorified so much by the Ministerial party, is not, after all, so real and substantial as it seems. The advantages will be discovered to be more showy and glittering in form than solid and useful in substance and realization. There is one uncomfortable fact in the present outlook of Australian trade, commerce, and industry which cannot be ignored in any Budget statement or any consideration of our finances. That is the unfortunate gradual reduction in the winning of gold in Australia, and the undoubted increase in the export of gold. There has been a downward tendency in the gold mining industry since 1903, when it obtained its maximum in the shape of a yield of nearly £16,000,000 sterling. Ever since then the production of gold has been substantially on the down grade, and this may be one of the factors in the financial pressure which is beginning to manifest itself, aggravated by the fact that our imports have been increasing disproportionately with our local manufactures and productions, resulting in the abnormal export of gold in order to make up the balance of trade. The production of gold in Australia has been gradually decreasing, as the following figures show : - 1907,£13,515,109; 1908, £13,058,853; 1909,£12,604,509;£12,604,509,£11,553,840; 191 1, £10,551,624. That, unfortunately, shows a downward tendency in gold production which must materially affect the productive industries and the financial power of the Australian Commonwealth. There has been, during the last three years, a very large increase in the export of gold. In 1907, gold to the value of £10,543,304 was exported, and in 1908 the value was £13,566,738. In that year £507,885 worth of gold was exported in excess of the. actual production. In 1911 £11,540,782 worth of gold was exported, or £989,158 worth in excess of the local gold production. These are startling features, which must receive attention at the hands of our financial advisers.
- There is nothing in that.

- This year there has been an even more remarkable increase in the export of gold. From January to June,1911, the export of gold from Australia was £3,764,483, while from January to June, 1912, it has been £6,677,080. These facts are certainly cause for anxiety.
- Gold is an export common dity in Australia.

- It is only used as an export when we are short of our ordinary merchandise or produce. That is the rule, excepting, of course, exports for special banking purposes, and it is certainly one of the most unfortunate signs of the times that during this period of unexampled prosperity such large exports of gold should be taking, place. The value of our imports in 191 1 was nearly £67,000,000, and to make up for the deficiency in our exports we had to export gold to the amount I have mentioned. 1 have had considerable trouble to get these figures. I had personally to go to the Statist's Office to-day to obtain them. It is a great pity that up-to-date figures of this kind, relating to imports and exports, are not included in the Budget.
- They never have been.

- I find, even in the Customs Department, a great difficulty in classifying their materials up to date. The imports for the first six months of this year amounted in value to . £37, 689, 580, and the value of the exports was £34,831,541, showing that our export trade this year has fallen off alarmingly, and that we shall have to export gold to make up the balance. I have shown the gradual growth of imports and the reduction of exports, in order to lead up to a few remarks on the Tariff question, and for that purpose I asked the Statist to give me the very latest figures available upon a group of items in the Tariff which come within the operation of some of the highest protective duties, and which may, therefore, be fairly regarded as typical of protected industries. I asked him to give me a return showing the value of the imports during 1910-11 and 1911-12 of such groups as apparel and attire, agricultural implements and machinery, other machinery, boots and shoes, hats and caps, and manufactures of metals. I think the return will be found very instructive, as showing the tendency to importation in classes of items which it is quite evident, upon an examination of the Tariff, come within the description of protected industries. The following table contains the information that has been furnished to me -

quote.para: Imports into Commonwealth.
For the years ending 30th June, 1910-11, and 30th June, 1911-12 : -

speech.para: On the face of this return the result does appear to be somewhat startling; and a searching examination is necessary to understand its real significance. I find, on inquiry from the Statist, that the item of apparel and attire includes all descriptions of softgoods and piece-goods, some of which are actually free. I have not the particulars of this year's imports, but I have those of last year in regard to apparel and attire; and apparently they will afford an index of the headings under which there has been an increase. From this return it seems that there has been a slight reduction in the imports of agricultural implements and machinery, a slight increase in the imports of hats and caps, and an increase in the imports of apparel and attire, other machinery, boots and shoes, and manufactures of metal. On coming to an analysis of the first item I find from a return for 1910-11, with which the Minister of Trade and Customs has favoured me, that apparently the imports of " apparel of fur n.e.i-, including articles cut into shape therefor," indicate the line along which there has been an increase. In 1 910 the value of imports under this heading was £1,337,710, and in 1911 the value was £1,528,941 ; and this suggests that there must have been a substantial increase in the importation of articles cut into shape. In 1911 there was a great increase in the importation of minor articles, also corsets, gloves, trimmings and ornaments, cotton, linen, and other piece-goods, " silk goods or containing silk," and one large item was "woollens or containing wool." I have troubled the Committee with these details in order to arrive at a fair idea of the meaning of the figures. We must go into details; we cannot draw a broad generalization. I think the result of the analysis I have roughly made indicates that in certain lines, at any rate, on which there are high protective duties, there has been a large increase in importation.

talk.start.para: - What does the honorable member propose?

- The conclusion to be drawn is that there has been a tendency to increase the imports of certain lines of protected goods; and I suggest that there should be annexed to the Customs Department some machinery or tribunal for conducting trustworthy inquiries into such matters.
- With a view to increase the duties?
- In other words, I am in favour of the creation of a Tariff Board.
- To increase the duties?
- To increase the duties if necessary.
- That is the only plank in the platform of honorable members opposite !

- I do not say that there would be sufficient work to keep a Tariff Board exclusively watching the Tariff; and the functions of the Board might very well be conferred on a great body such as the Inter- State Commission, who could watch the Tariff and report to Parliament any odd, abnormal changes in the increase of imports or the reduction of exports, and suggest any revision or adjustment necessary in the interests of trade and commerce or of Australian manufactures. I have had experience of the difficulties of such inquiries, and I know the necessity' for caution, prudence, and calm survey before submitting any Tariff proposals to Parliament. The last amended Tariff, submitted five or six years ago, had the advantage, at any rate, of being preceded by a searching investigation of the trade and commerce and the industrial relations of Australia. During the course of these investigations, in which the honorable member for Capricornia, other honorable members, and myself had the honour to participate, we heard evidence from all parts of the Commonwealth. We received about 700 complaints, and examined over 600 witnesses on both sides, with the result that we were able to present proposals that were, at any rate, backed up by evidence.
- What was the result?
- The result was that we arrived at a Tariff which, at the time, was considered fair, satisfactory, and, at the same time, scientific.
- Why is. the Tariff not so now ?

- A Tariff may be subject to conflicting changes, interests, and modifications in every trade. In the United States it has been found that the Tariff require?, constant supervision and periodical reports, so that Congress may have the advantage of full information in making any revision whenever necessary. I know that such assistance would be invaluable to a Minister of Customs. It is a very onerous task to submit Tariff alterations to Parliament merely on request by deputations from one side or the other ; and any Tariff revision, even on a limited scale, might well be preceded by inquiry, so that a Minister might come to Parliament knowing that he had sufficient material and a strong case. Under such circumstances, a Minister would have very little difficulty in rectifying anomalies, or bringing about substantial improvements or modifications.
- Would the honorable member have a Protectionist Board or a Free Trade Board?
- We ought to have a strong body, charged with a certain mandate. I do not know that we should depend so much on the individual opinions of the men as on the mandate committed to them.
- It would depend entirely on the individual opinions of the men.
- I do not: think it would be advisable to have a body consisting of strong partisans on one side or the other; but it would be advisable to have men of good and decided views.
- On both sides?
- We should certainly have men sympathetic with Australian industries.
- Hear, hear ! That is a very good lawyer's definition.
- It is near enough for my purpose.
- It is not near enough for me.

- At any rate, we ought to have men sympathetic with the recognised policy of the country. We should not put enemies to the recognised policy on such a Board, because they would not be in the position to' do the duty assigned to them with the justice that Parliament might expect. As a result of a prolonged study of the question, I am convinced that it is only fair, in a country like this, in dealing with such complex questions, to have a standing tribunal, to which Parliament could look - not merely the Minister, who is the mouthpiece of a party for the time being, but a tribunal, Board, or Commission, to whom the Minister or Parliament might refer the duty of the collection and formulation of evidence and information. The views of a Board so constituted would have great weight with, and be a great relief to, the Minister, as well as to members of Parliament.
- We should have the fight over again in the House.

- Nothing can deprive Parliament of the right of final review ; but Parliament is entitled to the assistance of the best evidence-gathering and recommending authority that can be secured. This view ought to commend itself to honorable members of all complexions of political thought. I now pass on to the Post and Telegraph Department, in which I feel an interest, having had the honour of presiding over it for nearly twelve months. Not being able to gather very much information from the Budget-papers in regard to the real position of the Department, I wrote to the Department itself, and 1 have been supplied with certain facts which I have summarized for the information of honorable members. I find that the revenue from the Post Office, including posts, telegraphs, and telephones in' 1908, when the Deakin Government were in office, amounted to £3,400,000 odd; while in 1911-12 it was £3,916,000 odd, showing an increase of £500,000 odd. That seems to be a very substantial increase in revenue, because it makes no allowance for the loss suffered by the adoption of penny postage. That loss has been variously estimated at from £300,000 to £400,000, but I think it would be impossible to arrive at any accurate calculation. Whatever it was, the increase in the revenue from the Postal Department during the three years amounted to £500,000. The principal sources of increase were as follows : - Postal, £57,641 ; telegraphs, £138,553; telephones, £310,980. The heavy increase in the revenue from telephones has evidently arisen very largely from the higher rates imposed by the present Administration, and also from the extension of net-works and the additional number of subscribers. In view of that large increase in the telephone revenue, I think that it is the duty of the Postmaster-General to present to Parliament a balance-sheet showing the exact condition of the telephonic service. When I was in office, there was a difference of opinion among the experts as to whether the telephone service, under the old system, was paying. With the concurrence of the House, I appointed a special Finance Committee, consisting of Mr. Whitton and Mr. Holmes, to investigate the telephonic service, and they found that under the old system it was paying, and that there was no necessity for any very drastic increase in the telephone rates. That was in 1909. Since then there has been an increase in the rates, and an increase in the number of subscribers. The additional revenue shown strongly suggests that the telephone service must be paying well, and that the time has arrived for a special investigation to show whether the increased rates imposed by the present Minister of External Affairs, when he held office as Postmaster-General, are justifiable. I believe that a thorough balance-sheet, giving receipts and expenditure under various headings - debiting all the sources of expenditure and crediting all the sources of revenue - would show that there was a balance on the right side, and that it is unnecessary to penalize the subscribers by high rates.
- Would the honorable member go back to the flat rate?

- I would go back to a. reduced rate. I believe that our telephones are paying better than is any other branch of the Public Service; that there is a growing tendency towards popularity; that there is a desire for the extension of the service throughout Australia; and that we should be quite justified in reducing the rates and making extensions, not only in the towns, but in the country districts. An extension of the system in country districts would make life there more attractive; it would bring the people to a greater extent within the lines of communication, and would so aid in putting people on the land.
- Which system does the honorable member favour?

- We have in operation a mixed system, but I do not desire that we should go back to any form other than the toll system. When I was in office, I said I believed the time would arrive when the toll system would have to be adopted, but I did not think a change was necessary under the existing circumstances. The Finance Committee which I appointed justified the retention of the system, but the time has arrived when we should make a thorough investigation, and see whether concessions cannot be made. I apprehend that it is not the desire of the Government to make a profit out of any of these services. The Minister of External Affairs himself said, when Postmaster-General, that he did not wish to make ' a profit out of them, and it it be shown that the telephone service is more than paying well, we should grant concessions in the shape of reduced charges' to the people in both town and country. This leads me to point to the necessity for the preparation of a balance-sheet relating to the whole Department of the Postmaster-General. When I was in office I directed the preparation of a departmental balance-sheet showing the in- come and expenditure of the whole service, and that balance-sheet was presented to Parliament on 26th August, 1909. It gave particulars of the income and expenditure of the three great branches; the various branches of the services were separated, and their revenue and expenditure shown under their several headings. That report was presented to Parliament in pursuance of a resolution of this House carried some years ago on the motion of Mr. Dugald Thomson, who then represented North Sydney. The resolution is still in force, and I should like to have from the Postmaster-General an explanation as to why effect has not been given to it from year to year. I gave instructions when in office that, in accordance with the resolution, a balance-sheet was to be prepared and- presented to Parliament every year; yet we find that nothing has since been done. I regret the absence of the Postmaster-General through illness, but I feel justified in again drawing the attention of the Committee to the necessity of bringing the telegraphic service well up-to-date in the matter of scientific equipment, and the adoption of scientific methods. Our Telegraph Service is not' as up-to-date as it ought to be. On a previous occasion I mentioned three important telegraphic instruments which I saw in the Central Telegraph Office, London, last year, but which have not yet found a place in the Telegraph Service of the Commonwealth. They are the Creed receiver; the Hughes telegraph instrument, and the Baudot telegraph instrument. I mention these names once more in order that honorable members may not forget them, and in the hope that the the Postmaster- General will insist upon his Department being brought up to date. Those instruments are required, not for ornamentation, but for practical use. I was informed when in London that they effected a great deal of saving, not only in respect of capital expenditure, but in labour - that their use resulted in a material saving in respect of wires and service. We should have them. The Postmaster-General promised me twelve months ago that he would make inquiries in the matter. [ wish to know whether those inquiries have been made, and whether any action has been taken. I propose now to make a few general observations regarding the growth of the Public Service - the increased number of governmental functions which have been established by appropriations in connexion with this and other Governments, and which have resulted in an increased number of Government employe's. The secondary result of that increase of functions and increase in the number of Government employes has been the growth of political or official patronage, and the gradual development of a bureaucratic system in this country which ought to be brought within the control of the law. During the last two years , while the Labour party have been in office, Ministers have made 134 appointments to offices carrying salaries over £300 per annum, and representing a total of £74,000 a year. These appointments were made by Ministers in the exercise of uncontrolled political patronage, apart from, and regardless of, the Public Service Commissioner. During the same period, the Public Service Commissioner has only made thirty-six appointments to offices, carrying a salary exceeding£300 a year, and these represent total salaries of £15,000 per annum. The Public Service Act was passed in the early days of Federation with the object of purifying the Service, and securing a guarantee that public servants would be appointed regardless of political or departmental influence, and apart from personal considerations. No doubt, the control of permanent appointments now rests with the Public Service Commissioner; but, unfortunately, in the drafting of the Act a loophole was left for the exercise of political and departmental patronage of a very serious and extensive character. These are to be found in the sections relating to temporary employment, and, as they are called, exempt hands. In order to give honorable members some idea of the extent of the temporary employment in the Service, and of the appointment of exempt hands, let me quote the following figures relating to exempt hands, not including the military and parliamentary officers : - Exempt hands, 1909, 13,675; 1910, 14.954. Temporary hands, 1909, 2,725; 1910, 3,308;or an increase from 16,400 to 18,262. In 1910 there were 12,187, and in 1911 13,233 permanent officers. The total number of officers in the Commonwealth, temporary, exempt, and permanent, was, in 1910, 28,587, and, in 1911, 31,485. The appointment, employment, retention, and dismissal of those men, women," and girls depend entirely on departmental or political influence. Things would not be so bad if the figures were not growing, but the tendency seems to be to enlarge the area of government, to create new kinds of employment, and to substitute public officers for contractors. Within the last few years, we have had established a Cordite Factory, a Woollen Cloth" Factory, a Clothing Factory, a Small Arms Factory, a Harness and Saddlery Factory-
- A Steam Laundry.

- In the Northern Territory, there is to be a Steam Laundry, a market garden, and Commonwealth mines. Our friends opposite are taking advantage of their opportunities to embark on large Socialistic experiments. What is necessary is legislation to regulate the employment of those whose services are required in these factories. At the present time, all these employes are outside the Public Service Act, and their appointment is governed either by Ministers, or by departmental officers. This unsatisfactory state of things should not be allowed to continue.
- I understand that the manager of each factory engages the hands that he requires.

- There has been a growth of the bureaucracy which the honorable member for Bourke denounced the other night. These appointments should not be left to the independent judgment of managers, without the oversight and regulation of Parliament. I have had a plan prepared showing the vast expenditure on these Institutions. As they grow, the hands employed in them will increase, and something must be done to provide satisfactory conditions of management. The fitters in the Telephone Department are artisans who have a defined and recognised position in the Public Service. Their appointment, pay, promotion, and the like do not depend on political patronage. The employment in the Government factories should be controlled in like manner by Act of Parliament. I have ascertained - that the Cordite Factory, with its site and buildings, cost for establishment, including machinery, plant, and equipment, £991935 ; the Woollen Factory, £27,983; the Clothing Factory, ^26,787 ; the Small Arms Factory, £170,749 ; and the Harness and Saddlery Factory, £10,250; a total of ^335, 704- That is the capital cost to date of these factories for the manufacture of Government stores and materials, no account having been taken of any loss that may have been incurred. The Treasury is not in possession of balance-sheets showing how these institutions are being worked. I have contended for the production of a balance-sheet to show the operations of the Telephone Service and of the Post Office Department, and I am justified in contending for the production of balance-sheets in connexion with each Budget to show the profit and loss of each of these factories. There should be some understanding on the subject. Matters should not be allowed to drift, and managers should not be permitted to carry on at their own sweet will, without responsibility, or being called to account. These factories should be worked on business lines. Why do not honorable members opposite demand balance-sheets ?
- None of the factories has been working for a year yet.

- Some of them have been working for more than a year, but no balance-sheet has been presented. They are working on Trust Funds, the cost of their maintenance not being voted by Parliament, so that there has Been nothing to show what they cost. If honorable members have the power, by all means let them provide for Socialism, or nationalization, but surely they are not above carrying on their factories on business lines.
- Balance-sheets will be available in connexion with every factory.

- Parliament should insist on their production from the first. I advise honorable members to read the last report of the Public Service Commissioner. These reports are not as well known as they should be, and the last one came to hand just at the end of the session. The Public Service Commissioner is instructed to report to Parliament, to keep members in touch with the grievances, difficulties, and details of the Service. _ I have not time to read the extracts which I should like to read, but I shall give honorable members one or two sentences to excite their interest: This is what the Public Service Commissioner says about the employment of temporary hands -

quote.para: While the provisions of the law are as indicated, a regrettable omission occurred in the failure to provide for a system of selection for employment which would remove any possibility of undue influence, and enable temporary or casual work to be distributed on fair grounds without favour to any person. It must be acknowledged that where opportunities occur foi the exercise of patronage, they are liable to be availed of, and, in the absence of restriction as to the method of engaging temporary assistance, the greatest temptation exists to find work for solicitous applicants, irrespective of the requirements of Departments, or of the claims of other applicants for prior consideration. And the danger does not end at this stage, as once having secured temporary engagement by means of undue influence, the same influence is brought into play to prevent the services of temporary hands being dispensed with. Viewing, the matter not only from an economical stand-point, but also from that of efficiency, the present system is detrimental to Departmental interests; and nothing but demoralization of the Permanent Service can result from a wasteful introduction of temporary hands.

speech.para: Those are weighty words, which should re,ceive the attention of honorable members. They show that the present method of appointing temporary hands tends to demoralization, and some of the scandals recently exposed may have been due to it. The Commissioner points out that men have been selected without proper regard to efficiency, and retained in 'disregard of the claims of justice. This is the report of the Public Service Commissioner, and not of any newspaper. Again, he complains that in many cases temporary hands have been retained out of sympathy when not wanted. Think of that 1 He says -

quote.para: It was shown that the tendency was most pronounced in many instances to disregard financial considerations by retaining the services of temporary hands out of sympathy for the individual, despite the reasons for the continuance of the employment having disappeared.

speech.para: In another passage he says -

quote.para: Instances have occurred where irregularities of a serious nature in respect to employment have been reported, and where persons who have never even complied with the provisions of the Act, as to registration, have been placed on the Temporary Staff. In one State four men were engaged by the Department in this way, and, when it is stated that two of these persons were considered to be ineligible for registration, owing to previous bad records when in the permanent employ of the Department, the gravity of the position is apparent. These cases were reported to the Auditor-General, and it is probable that the officers responsible for the irregularity will be surcharged the amount of salary which has been illegally paid to the temporary hands.

talk.start.para: - That is not Ministerial.

- I am saying that that shows the necessity for an amendment of the law to regulate the employment of temporary hands in a definite way, and to prevent the exercise of either political or departmental patronage. Even in the employment of men to do temporary work, or exempt hands, we should insist upon their undergoing some test to show their efficiency. We should not let them be put on as an act of favour or patronage. The complaint of the Public Service Commissioner is that even persons required for temporary purposes are put on without regard to efficiency, and very often without regard to registration.
- If you wanted a man for telephone tunnelling, what examination would you expect him to go through ?
- The Commissioner suggests that the Department might have a recognised system of choice and selection to determine efficiency. He says -

quote.para: I am far from satisfied that the heavy expenditure during the past year is justified from any stand-point, bearing in mind the large additions to the Permanent Staff of officers in the two principal States, and this view is strengthened by the many instances which have come within my notice of irregularities, for which there can be no satisfactory explanation.

speech.para: That is our own Commissioner reporting to the House irregularities for which there is no satisfactory explanation. In another part he says -

quote.para: It has apparently not been recognised that, in conferring a favour upon applicants who were in a position to exert influence -

speech.para: There is a distinct allusion to the exercise of influence.

talk.start.para: - Social influence.

- I do not care whether it is social or political, the Commissioner refers to the fact that influence is being exerted - an injustice is at the same time being inflicted on deserving men who have relied upon securing a share of temporary work in their proper order of registration.
- Are they not put on in their order of registration?

- The Commissioner reports that, although there is a book in the office presided over by him for the registration of applications for employment, men are being put on without reference to the employment register by departmental officers.
- That is not fair.

- It is a breach of the law. It is time that Ministers insisted upon the enforcement of the law in reference to temporary employment; but there is a still more insidious way of evading the provisions of the Public Service Act requiring qualifications for service. That is by withdrawing certain classes of employment altogether from the Act, under the term of "exempt employment." In this report, which was made last November, the Commissioner refers to some things that were news to me, and I think will be news to a number of honorable members. He says -

quote.para: Action has been taken during the past few years to specially exempt classes of employe's such as casual letter-carriers, postal assistants, telephonists, and telegraph messengers in country districts; casual messengers in metropolitan districts; linemen, labourers, and tradesmen employed outside metropolitan areas;labourers and mechanics employed in conduit work; watchmen and navvies engaged on underground cable work, &c.

speech.para: Those make a large group of men actually exempt from the ordinary operations of the Public Service Act. Their employment is vested in departmental heads, without any conditions or regulations, or any mode of choice being determined. It is a mere matter of favour, influence, and pressure brought to bear. I am just as much against departmental patronage as against political influence. It might, perhaps, be more objectionable, and therefore I think all this group of employes ought to be withdrawn from departmental influence. Why should men be dependent for employment as letter-carriers, tradesmen, mechanics, &c, on departmental officers, overseers, or superintendents ? There ought to be a recognised method of registration, and certain defined qualifications for a man who wants to obtain employment of this kind. The work might be temporary, or, if it is exempt employment, it might even be permanent, and it certainly should not depend on the ipse dixit, favour, or preference of anybody. There should be a regular standard of choice and mode of selection, as recommended by the Minister himself. If honorable members will support their own Commissioner in a proposition of that kind, it will be a great relief to themselves. It will save their being called upon to exercise influence either on

Ministers or officers to get work of a temporary or exempt character. I do not think that anything is to be gained by members of Parliament in being bothered by employment questions. It is best to allow them to be determined by certain regular tribunals authorized by law. When men require either temporary or exempt billets, they ought to comply with certain conditions, and fulfil certain requirements, and be able to get the work without fear, favour, or affection. The Commissioner's summary is -

quote.para: It will be seen from the above résumé of the conditions governing temporary and exempted employment, that under the present unsatisfactory methods of regulating the selection and appointment of persons for this class of work, the inducements for the exercise of pressure in securing Government employment are very considerable.

speech.para: Those are the representations of a statutory officer appointed by Parliament. They are, I think, of sufficient weight to command the attention of the House. They should constrain honorable members to insist upon an amendment of the law to provide for an improved method of determining the conditions and qualifications of service, and an improved mode of choice in all branches of Commonwealth employment.
Progress reported.

debateinfo.title: PINE CREEK TO KATHERINE RIVER RAILWAY SURVEY BILL

quote.para: That it is expedient that an appropriation of revenue be made for the purposes of a Bill for an Act to authorize the survey of a route for a line of railway in the Northern Territory from Fine Creek to the Katherine River.

talk.start.para: . - Will the Minister say at what stage he proposes to take the House into his confidence with respect to the circumstances of the survey ?
- I shall deal with the matter on the second reading.
- I should have liked to hear an explanation before that stage.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Resolution reported and adopted.

quote.para: That Mr. Thomas and Mr. Hughe's do prepare and bring in the Bill to carry out the foregoing resolution.

speech.para: Bill presented by Mr. Thomas, and read a first time.
